title: Students sweltering in classrooms

organizations.name: st helens park school’s p & c association

Picture: Robert Pozo A school P & C are raising their own money to fund airconditioning in sweltering classrooms Daniel Zautsen, Macarthur Chronicle Campbelltown February 16, 2017 6:10pm 
PARENTS at Woodland Road Public School are so desperate to get airconditioning put into the school they’ve started fundraising to fix the problem themselves. 
The St Helens Park school’s P & C Association has started the fundraising after the recent heatwave meant many students went home from school, unable to cope with the heat. 
The school’s P & C president Lee-Anne Hanney said the association had been disappointed by a lack of government action in providing the school with airconditioning. 
“It’s something parents at the school have been asking about for a while and we just finished some other fundraising projects so decided we should do something,” she said. 
“(The heat) affects the students’ learning as the teachers are spending time trying to find ways to cool them down instead of teaching. 
“During the heatwave I went into the school one day and there were about 20 students who had already gone home and more who were preparing to.” media_camera The school’s P & C are doing their own fundraising to raise money for airconditioning in the classrooms. Picture: Robert Pozo 
Ms Hanney said the P & C was aware providing airconditioning would be expensive but was determined to raise the money. 
“The problem we have is not just providing airconditioning. The school’s whole electrical system would need replacing to accommodate airconditioners,” she said. 
“We’ve got several of our regular fundraising activities planned and we’re looking at applying for a few grants.” 
Campbelltown state Labor MP Greg Warren said many Campbelltown schools went without airconditioning each day. 
“The problem is the electrical systems, the cabling, grid and switchboards, at many of these schools aren’t able to handle putting airconditioning in,” he said. 
“It would be costly but I think it needs to happen. 
“The government boasts about a $4 billion surplus but that’s a great thing when you’ve got kids sweltering away in classrooms while we’re expecting them to learn.” 
Documents obtained under freedom of information by Mr Warren’s office showed that across the Macarthur region there is a backlog of maintenance work of more than $31 million, with $10 million in the Campbelltown electorate. 
According to 2016-17 information obtained by Mr Warren’s office, the maintenance backlog in Campbelltown would is over $9 million with just $822,000 funding planned for the electorate. 
“One of the most important things we need to do is have our infrastructure in place at our schools,” Mr Warren said. 
According to the figures obtained by Mr Warren there is about a $14 million backlog in Macquarie Fields with $1 million pledged for 2016-17. 
In Camden, a $6.5 million backlog had almost $700,000 in funding.
